$  checked = false,
$  htmlAttributes = null 
)

generate checkbox. will generate a value (0) even if unchecked, no more javascript fiddeling!

Parameters:
string $name name of the input-tag
bool $checked if checkbox should be checked or not. will be overwritten if we land here again after the request
array $htmlAttributes tag-attributes
Returns:
string html

Definition at line 103 of file form.php.

FormHelper::error ( $  name,
$  errorString 
)

return error message if the previously displayed form had any validation errors. obviously only works if you did a validate inside your models action.

Parameters:
string $name name-portion of input-tag
string $errorString string to display on error
Returns:
string empty string if no error, otherwise errorstring inside configured error-tag-template

Definition at line 116 of file form.php.

FormHelper::fieldName ( $  name  ) 

create name-portion of tag, depends on wether we use a model or not: if no model is used simply returns name, otherwise returns 'model[name]'

Parameters:
mixed $name name-portion of the input tag
Returns:
string html

FormHelper::select ( $  name,
$  optionElements,
$  selected = null,
$  selectAttr = array (),
$  optionAttr = array (),
$  showEmpty = false 
)

build select/option tags

<samp> $arr = array('blue'=>'Blue color','red'=>'Red color'); echo $html->selectTag('gameinput',$arr,'red'); </samp>

Parameters:
string $fieldName name-part of the select-tag
array $optionElements array with elements (key=option-tags value-part, name=between option tag)
string $selected keyname of the element to be default selected
array $selectAttr array of attributes of the select-tag, for example "class"=>"dontunderline"
array $optionAttr array of attributes for each option-tag, for example "class"=>"dontunderline"
boolean $showEmpty if we should display an empty option as the default selection so the user knows (s)he has to select something
Returns:
string html
